post.body: Really interesting tech! Lots of potential.

It would be amazing to have a github style service on zeronet. Unless I'm not understanding it right, all sites are strictly js, so this might be a bit of a challenge. At the least it would require a javascript git implementation, which I'm not even sure exists.

I really need to get more familar with javascript. I know my way around making sites using Python frameworks like Flask, Pyramid, etc., but haven't learned enough js to make anything useful.. Zeronet is a good reason to dive in I guess.

I seem to be having issues recently creating zeronet sites. The content.json file is created correctly, but always shows as unavailable. I'm not sure if this is a bug, or an issue with my install. I'll have to try it again from another box.

ZeroMe is currently showing 1327 registered users. This is 200 more than when I checked a day or two ago. The total number isn't all that large, but it'll be interesting to watch where it goes if the pace keeps up.

As an experiment, I created a site with the PyPy.js interpreter only. You can find it here: 
http://127.0.0.1:43110/18tTD88a3dNcDriQ8Fxet7Mnc3NhrQLph8/
Most of standard library is included to play around with, so it's a bit big. You'll get a messag asking you to increase the site limit on first visit. 

For those unfamiliar with PyPy, it's basically compliant Python interpreter JIT compilation, which as been itself compiled to Javascript with emscripten. The official site is here: http://pypyjs.org/

It would be interesting to use the merged site, and/or optional files feature to create a version that could be used as a base for other sites written in Python.

comment.body: Thanks for the tips, guys.  I looked around, and found gitlet: https://github.com/maryrosecook/gitlet

(Oops, I expected the Enter key to go to the next line, not commit). It's nice to see that this is at least feasable. It should be doable, if git commits are handled in a similar fashion to how forum posts and stuff are done.
Hmm, I keep getting a "content.json not found" message. There are plenty of peers, but it just cannot validate that.

@Habit: Go to the ZeroMe home page. Scroll down a little, and look for the "New Users" section on the right. Click "browse all". You should see a page will all of the current users, and at the very bottom is the total user count.
@Habit: It's not really so obvious. It took me a moment to find it again today!
